newsitem.title: HONG KONG: China's Hainan Airlines applies to issue B shares.
newsitem.headline: China's Hainan Airlines applies to issue B shares.

text.p: Hainan Airlines intends to make an offer of 75 million class B shares and list the stock on the Shanghai bourse, a company spokeswoman said on Monday.

The spokeswoman told the China Securities Bulletin the airline had submitted an application on the offer of B shares to the China Securities Regulatory Commission with the support of the Hainan provincial government. B shares are reserved for foreign investors.
If the offer is approved, Hainan Airlines would be China's first public civil aviation company, she said.

Hainan Airlines already is the first Chinese airline to become a foreign joint venture. American Aviation Investment, a fund partially controlled by U.S. financier George Soros, took a 25 percent stake for US$25 million in November last year.

The spokeswoman said Hainan Airlines, which became a joint-stock entity in 1993, has total share capital of 400 million shares. These include 100 million shares held by American Aviation, 240 million held by China-based institutions and 60 million class A shares for local investors. The latter were offered at one yuan per share in early 1993.
If the B share offer goes through, Hainan Airlines would use the proceeds to expand its operation, she said.
Hainan Airlines, based in Haikou, capital of China's island province of Hainan, operates 13 rented planes, including nine Boeing 737 jets, within mainland China.

It had net earnings of 81 million yuan in 1995, 87 million yuan in 1994 and 67 million yuan a year earlier, the spokeswoman said. She did not issue a profit forecast for this year or provide an explanation for the profit drop in 1995.
Shenzhen J&A Securities has been named as the preliminary domestic lead underwriter for the offer, while an international coordinator had yet to be selected, she added.
